text: It's like it's deep and not deep. I think it's two parts. I kind of just hit on it, right? Why do we invest? Why do we even invest? There's a goal. So I think that has to be paramount. And that's to some degrees because of the way people approach the success rate concept and the flexibility of your goals. I think that's not being addressed properly. I think Monte Carlos are way better than they were in the last decade ago, two decades ago. I'm still critical on the success rate below 100% concept. But then also taking the best understanding that we have today around human behavior on risky views, risky propositions, which is prospect theory or some derivative of it, implementing that as opposed to a simple mean variance power law construction, I think that should be done as well. I think those are the two things, right? Respecting someone's goals first. And then really trying, digging as deep as we can around their risk preferences and bringing that into the portfolio. Even though a lot of times it might not always, it's not necessarily going to give you better expected returns. That's kind of a challenge for an advisor. It's a principal agent problem. So I'm going to give you something that respects loss aversion. And now you're only going to make 4% a year instead of your buddy next door making eight. I have to have that conversation. So I get it. But it feels like a more responsibility to fight that fight.
